title: Kathy Griffin and Aubrey Plaza light up the red carpet at DTLA premiere of A Hell Of A Story
text:
It's Kathy Griffin's first theatrically-released comedy special, and her twenty-first overall.

And the 58-year-old comedienne looked proud as punch of her achievement on Saturday night, as she took to the red carpet of the DTLA Film Festival in Downtown Los Angeles.

The Suddenly Susan star was joined by fellow funny lady Aubrey Plaza for the red carpet stroll.

Lovely ladies: Kathy Griffin [L] looked proud as punch of her achievements on Saturday night, as she took to the red carpet of the DTLA Film Festival in Downtown Los Angeles with actress Aubrey Plaza

Kathy was decked out in dark jeans and a black T-shirt promoting her comedy special.

The star added inches to her 5ft3in frame in a pair of towering heels.

Her Legion starring companion turned heads in an animal print dress, paired with flat soled shoes.

Star power: The Suddenly Susan star was joined by fellow funny lady Aubrey Plaza for the red carpet stroll

Her own best advertisement: Kathy was decked out in dark jeans and a black T-shirt promoting her comedy special

Griffin has called herself 'unemployable' in the wake of her Donald Trump photo scandal and financed A Hell Of A Story herself.

The scandal erupted in May 2017 when Griffin posed with the bloodied mask in a photoshoot with photographer Tyler Shields.

Griffin captioned it with a reference to 'blood coming out of his wherever' - a play on Trump's controversial comments about TV host Megyn Kelly.

But the photo was widely understood as a threat about the President's violent death.

She faced condemnation from across the political spectrum, including from the President himself who said Griffin 'should be ashamed of herself'.

Trump called the stunt 'sick', adding that his young son Barron was 'having a hard time with this'.

Wild thing! Her Legion starring companion turned heads in an animal print dress, paired with flat soled shoes

Griffin was dropped from CNN's New Year's Eve show and co-host Anderson said the photo was 'clearly disgusting and completely inappropriate'.

She had been the co-host of CNN's New Year's Eve broadcast for 10 years before she was fired in the aftermath of the photo.

The comedian initially retreated, admitting she had gone 'way too far' and asking for 'forgiveness'.

But she has since reversed her apology. Two days into the fallout from the photo, she began to film on her iPhone to capture what was happening in the moment.

The result was the part documentary, part comedy special screened on Saturday night.
